hints_html:
Recall that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f^{-1}(D)\end{aligned}\]

is the pre-image of the set \(D\), that is the set containing all the elements that are mapped by \(f\) into the set \(D\) and that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(C)\end{aligned}\]

is the image of the set \(C\), that is the set all the images of elements of the set \(C\).
hints_raw:
Recall that

:<math>\displaystyle f^{-1}(D) </math>

is the pre-image of the set <math> D </math>, that is the set containing all the elements that are mapped by <math>f</math> into the set <math>D</math> and that

:<math>\displaystyle f(C) </math>

is the image of the set <math> C </math>, that is the set all the images of elements of the set <math>C</math>.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
\[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(D) = \{ a \in A \mid f(a) \in D \}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} f(C) = \{ f(c)\mid c\in C \}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
:<math>f^{-1}(D) = \{ a \in A \mid f(a) \in D \}</math>

and

:<math>f(C) = \{ f(c)\mid c\in C \}. </math>
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f : A \to B\end{aligned}\]

be a function and let

\[\begin{aligned} C \subseteq A\end{aligned}\]

and \(D \subseteq B\). Define the sets

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f^{-1} (D)\end{aligned}\]

and \(\displaystyle f (C)\).
statement_raw:
Let
:<math>\displaystyle f : A \to B </math>
be a function and let
:<math> C \subseteq A </math> and <math> D \subseteq B </math>.
Define the sets
:<math>\displaystyle f^{-1} (D)</math> and <math>\displaystyle f (C) </math>.
